loans.name: Mrs. Sim Horm Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Seventeen people who live in Kdol village in TaK. province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Sim H., who is 49 years old, is the village bank president, selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their businesses.

Mrs. Sim H. owns a general store in the local village where she sells groceries to earn a large profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Touch Ouch, is a farmer who owns a one-hectare (2.5-acre) plot of land that he uses to cultivate rice to sell to support his family.

Since her business is going well, Mrs. Sim H. wants to expand it. So, to achieve this purpose, she is seeking a loan to buy more groceries to sell.

Mrs. Sim H. is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, another is a fisherman, and the other is studying in the local school.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mrs. Saroeun Phul Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan, located in Kdol village in Takeo province, has eighteen people. They have all selected Mrs. Saroeun P., who is 29 years old, as the village bank president. They will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their businesses.

Mrs. Saroeun P. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare (1.25-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vorn V., is a construction worker.

Mrs. Saroeun P. faces a problem in that her field has infertile soil. So, to improve production, she is asking for a loan to buy fertilizer. With the rest of the loan she will hire a farm laborer to help her to grow rice.

Mrs. Saroeun P. is the mother of four children, two of whom are attending the local school while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and to hire a farm laborer

loans.name: Mrs. Sokha Meas Village Bank Group

texts.en:
In Kdol village, Takeo province, sixteen people make up this village bank loan. They have selected Mrs. Sokha M., who was born in 1961, as the village bank president. The members will use their portions of the loan in varied ways to support their businesses.

Mrs. Sokha M. is a farmer who owns a half-hectare (1.25-acre) plot of land that she uses to cultivate rice to sell to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Vannat Chea, is a cow middleman.

Since her husband’s business is going well Mrs. Sokha M. wants to expand it. So, to improve this business, she is applying for a loan to enable him to buy more cows to sell.

Mrs. Sokha M. is the mother of three children, one of whom is a seamstress in a garment factory, while the others are attending the local public school.

loans.use: To enable her husband to buy more cows to sell

loans.name: Mahmadjon

texts.ru: Ширинов Махмадчон житель города Курган-Тюбе. Возраст, 24 года. Женат, имеет одного ребенка. Жена, домохозяйка. Живет в семной квартире. Клиент не имеет высшего образования. Занимается торговлей на рынке. Продает национальные женские платья. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара. В будущем он хочет купить собственную квартиру.
texts.en:
Mahmadchon S. is a resident of the city of Qurgan-Tube. He is 24 years old, married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. Mahmadchon lives in the family apartment. The client does not have a higher education. He is involved in retails sales at a market. Mahmadchon sells national women's dresses. He is requesting this loan in order to expand the merchandise assortment. In the future, he wants to buy his own apartment.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding merchandise assortment

loans.name: Venus

texts.en:
Venus U. is from the village of Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 33 years old. Venus is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Venus owns and operates a business in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Venus has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Venus joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venus is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Venus from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Danny

texts.en:
Danny L. is from the village of Cabisera 5, Ilagan, Isabela. He is 30 years old. Danny is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Danny plants and harvests rice to sell. Danny has been engaged in his business for over 8 years and earns approximately 25,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Danny joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Danny is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Danny from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Cristy

texts.en:
Cristy V. is from the town of Banga. She is 33 years old. Cristy is married and has 2 children aged six and two. To make a living, Cristy owns and operates a business raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business is from planting and harvesting rice, which she later sells. She hopes to grow her farming business and raise pigs. Cristy has been farming for over 8 years.

A few years back, she opened a sari-sari store to generate daily income. She says she is very thankful to have the store because it helps her to meet her daily needs.

Cristy joined CEVI to access financial services so she can improve her business and living situation. Cristy has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Cristy is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers and seeds. She also plans to purchase piglets to raise.

This loan will be the second loan taken out by Cristy from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to make improvements to her house and save for future emergencies.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and seeds. She also plans to purchase piglets.

loans.name: Awadallah

texts.en:
Awadallah is a 29-year-old man from Jenin. He got married a couple of years ago. Awadallah had to borrow money from friends to pay for his wedding expenses because he is a school teacher with a relatively low income. Therefore, he came to FATEN to take a $2,000 dollar loan to repay his debts.

Awadallah is thinking of starting a business to guarantee a better future for his family in Ramallah and is looking forward to work in the Ministry of Higher Education.

In the picture above, Awadallah apears in the FATEN office.

loans.use: Pay off wedding expenses

loans.name: Eilen

texts.en:
Eilen L. is from the town of Banga. She is 37 years old. Eilen is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Eilen owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector, running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Eilen has been engaged in her business for over 15 years. She also started raising hogs for fattening. She hopes for her new venture to succeed.

Eilen joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Eilen has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Eilen is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell and feed for the pigs. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Eilen from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell and feed for the pigs

loans.name: Sharifan's Group

texts.en:
Sharifan lives with her family in the historic city called Lahore in Pakistan. She is a fifty-year-old housewife who stays at home and does household work. 
Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market which used to do well but these days, being the only grocery shop in the community, he has to put the maximum amount of groceries in it to enable him to meet the demand of his customers.  

Therefore, Sharifan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy more groceries for his grocery shop. By putting more groceries into his shop he will be able to meet the demand of his customers which will help him to increase the clientele base and the profit as well. 
She is a regular client of Asasah. She has successfully completed two loans with Asasah and now has applied for a third loan. With the previous loans she has maintained good credit and never missed any single meeting.  She hopes that her loan experience this time will be a good one too.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Anis' Group

texts.en:
Anis lives Lahore, Pakistan, which is very famous for its history and architecture. To help her husband support their family, she sells ready-made clothes which she orders from different suppliers. She started this business last year, after receiving her first loan from Asasah, and is happy to report that her small company is doing very well. Anis would like to continue helping her husband, who makes a living as a printer. He recently received a large order and needs to buy toner and paper to complete it. She has applied for this loan to allow him to buy these supplies. We believe she will pay the loan back because she has a strong record of making payments on time and has never missed a meeting of our organization.

Note: In this photo of her loan group, we see one of the embroidered dresses she has made.

loans.use: To buy supplies for a printing business

Analyn E. lives in the village of Manaoag. She is 31 years old, married, has three school-aged children, and makes a living as a rice farmer. She has been in this line of work for more than seven years and earns 20,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2007, Analyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid seven previous loans from ASKI, and is now applying for a new one, for 20,000 PHP, to buy fertilizer for her farm. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to improve her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anurathan's Group

texts.en:
Anurathan K. has two children, in the sixth and eighth grade respectively, and leads this loan group. Her husband makes a living by selling cattle, and recently went into business on his own. Anurathan helps her husband by handling the sale of cows in the local market. The success of this business has allowed them to start building their own home, and they are working hard to finish construction. Anurathan has applied for this loan to buy more cows to raise and sell.

Anurathan’s partners are:
Karamat S., 40, has three children and helps her husband make a living selling cattle. They plan to use this loan to buy two cows, and hope some day to buy a van to help transport their small herd. 

Aizada K., 37, has three children and makes a living selling watermelons, which she brings from neighboring villages to the local market. She plans to use her portion of this loan to buy more watermelons to sell, and pay to transport them to the local market.  

Aizada T., 36, has two children. Her husband has a truck and makes a living shipping goods while she sells cattle. Her husband helps her transport these cows from neighboring villages to the local market. She plans to use her portion of this loan to buy more cattle, and do repair work on their house. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps: People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice is married with eight children, all of whom are at school. She does not take care of additional family members. She owns and lives in a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses are school fees, food and paying utility bills.
Alice owns a stall selling second-hand clothes at her home in Kalerwe. She has been in this business for many years. She sells, both retail and wholesale, to all categories of people from the local area. She buys her stock from Owino market and uses public transport to and from the market, which she visits once a week.
Alice works six days a week and depends on her job for a living. Her business challenges include seasonality and transporting the bales from Owino market in Kampala to her home in Kalerwe. Alice decided to join Kiva partner, MCDT, because it was charging low interest. She plans to use her loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Shehla's Group

texts.en:
Shehla is a housewife. She stays at home and does household work like taking care of her children and taking care of her home, etc. She lives in the city called Lahore with her husband and children in Pakistan. 

Her husband is a hairdresser and operates a barber shop in the market. He has seven years of experience in this business. Earlier, he worked for someone else but then started independently two years ago. By the grace of God, he has been able to establish his shop very quickly and his work started getting acknowledged among his customers. 
 
Shehla has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount he will buy necessary items, such as scissors, hair creams and gels, for his barber shop. She is hopeful that her husband will be able to increase his business and income with a positive use of investment in it.

loans.use: Purchase necessary items for barber shop

loans.name: Ma. Luisa

texts.en:
Forty-one-year-old Ma. Luisa M. is from the town of Banga. She is married and has two children, aged 5 and 2. She grows hogs for fattening and sale. She has been doing this for more than six years already. She was also able to put up a sari-sari (variety) store, where she sells sugar, soy sauce and other items her neighbors usually look for daily. Her family also owns a rice farm that her husband manages. She helps sell their harvest at their store and at their town's market. One of Luisa's goals right now is to save for her children's education.

Ma. Luisa joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ma. Luisa has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Ma. Luisa is requesting a new loan of 8000 Philippine pesos, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This will be the second loan taken out by Ma. Luisa from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia is married to M. S. and lives in Lahore, Pakistan with her family. She is a housewife and carries out her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother very well. Her husband operates a breakfast stall in the market. He sells a Punjabi traditional food called Naan Chaney, which is a very famous food, particularly among the people of Lahore. He has been selling this traditional food for the last nine years. After the nine-year-struggle, he is now being rewarded with many customers and a good amount of earnings. Razia also helps him prepare food so he serves his customers in the morning without any delay. 

He now wants to introduce another Punjabi dish called “Biryani” (rice with meat, egg or vegetables and spices), which is also popular with the people of Lahore. Therefore, Razia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband’s food stall. With the loan, he will buy items such as “rice, spices, cooking oil and other necessary items” in bulk and will introduce a Biryani dish to his customers. She hopes that her husband will be able to achieve his plan and increase his monthly income.

He is very good at his art and very famous for his quality work. As a result, he receives a good number of orders, which sometimes creates problems for him to fulfill on time. He wants to buy another sewing machine and hire a worker who will assist him in fulfilling the larger orders on time. 

Therefore, Saira has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband buy another sewing machine to expand his business. She is hopeful that it will prove to be a good investment in her husband’s tailoring business.

Zozan is a 39-year-old mother of three sons and one daughter. Her husband, Nafez, works in the vegetable market in Jenin, a city in Palestine. One of Zozan's sons is a National Palestinian Authority employee who has a very low salary because he is a college student. The rest of her children are school students.

Zozan's husband, Nafez, appears in the picture here in FATEN's office, because Zozan is a conservative woman who doesn't like having her picture published.

loans.name: Najeebullah 315 Group

texts.en: Najeebullah is the group leader of Najeebullah 315 group. He is resident of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is married with five children and is responsible for all expenses of the house and family. He owns a small shop in which he sells vegetables and fresh fruits. With the income from his work, he supports his family members. He needs the loan to purchase more vegetables and different kinds of fruits to attract more clients. He hopes to progress more in the future and be a good business dealer.

loans.use: To purchase more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en: Patrick is a 34-year-old farmer who wants a loan to purchase watermelon seeds and pay labor as he expands his garden of watermelon. He is a father of six children who live in a semi-permanent house in the district of Kyenjojo, Uganda. He is a farmer who has been in the business for two and a half years but faces a problem with pests on his agricultural products. He dreams of becoming a model farmer in his area.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and pay for labor .

loans.name: Shamim Akhter's Group

texts.en:
Shamim Akhter lives in Pakistan in the historic city called Lahore with her husband and children. She is a seamstress and sews clothes for her nearby clients. She has a worker who collects orders for her so she completes them on time and earns an income. 

Shamim fulfills her responsibilities as a housewife and a mother very efficiently as well. Her family respects her a lot for her courageous nature and dedication towards both her responsibilities. 

Her husband runs a grocery shop in the market. Every day he faces new challenges with other grocery shops. To conquer those challenges he has to perform extraordinarily. This can only happen when he fulfills the demand of his customers. 

Therefore, Shamim has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. He will be using the loan amount by adding grocery inventory to his grocery shop. She is hopeful that this loan amount will have a positive impact on her husband’s business.

loans.use: Purchase groceries for grocery shop

loans.name: Blessed Development Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
23-year-old N. Hadijjah has always taken exception to failure. Even if she is only three years into her beauty salon business, her sense of optimism has never been this high. With 400,000 shillings accruing to her business as monthly income, she is in a way bearing witness to what she preaches. With complete belief in her own worth, she has made progress. She credits her mother with setting her off and instilling in her  values that she has come to manifest in real life and in this case her business. 

In her salon, she mostly does hair dressing and weaving. At her young age, her single status is the last thing she is worried about, even with friends telling her to marry the father of her only child. With this loan, she wants to purchase more lotions in bulk for her beauty salon.

loans.use: bulk purchase of more lotions

loans.name: Tadeo

texts.en:
Tadeo, aged 73 years, is a married man with twenty children living in his own house in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He grows tea which he has sold for thirty years. He has an established tea garden but faces problems of prolonged droughts which affect the expected growth of the cash crop. He wants to see all his children well educated.

He wants a loan to buy manure and herbicides for his tea plantation.

loans.use: To buy manure and herbicides for his tea plantation

loans.name: Shagufta's Group

texts.en:
Shagufta is a housewife and lives with her family in a city called Lahore in Pakistan. She has applied for a loan for her husband who operates a cloth selling shop in the market. He goes to Faisalabad and Multan to buy different varieties of embroidered cloth to sell in his shop. 

With the loan amount, he will buy cloth in bulk that will minimize his cost of traveling and also cut his over-all cost due to bulk purchasing. 

Shagufta is very hopeful that this investment will bring a positive financial change to her husband’s business and her family will be able to enjoy better living conditions.

loans.use: Purchase cloth for resale

loans.name: Siama

texts.en: Siama S. is currently in the business of selling fresh cassava, Irish potatoes, and carrots at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fish and tomatoes to sell.  Siama is 25 years old and is married to a husband who is a businessman. She has two children and her children do not go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to buy land, build on it, and rent it out.

loans.use: Stock fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John G. Ndung’u  is thirty-six years old and married, but he does not have any children yet. His business is located by the roadside near  a primary school in Nairobi and is well known by the name Beba beba Hardware. He has been selling cement, iron sheets, paint, wire mesh, and other items. He sells to the local people and also to walk-ins from far from where his business is located. 

John has been doing this business for six months  now and has two employees. He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is financial constraints. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. He is using his loan of Kes 50,000 to buy more cement and rafters to sell to builders and meet the large demand. He hopes to be a wholesaler in the future. He is very hardworking, patient and determined.

loans.use: Cement and rafters

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice F. is from the village of Gappal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 26 years old. Alice is married and has 3 very young children. To make a living, Alice owns & operates a fruit and vegetable vending business. The main source of income for the business comes from selling fruits and vegetables in the community. Alice has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Alice joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Alice is requesting a new loan of 6000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the second loan taken out by Alice from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is married to a businessman with whom she has  two children; both of them are at school. She doesn’t take care of any additional family members.  She owns a stall in Nalukolongo market selling second-hand clothes and buys bales of clothes from Owino market, one of the busiest markets in Uganda. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She has been in this business for many years.  

Florence  sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale.   Florence  is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and educating her children up to university level. Her business challenges  include thieves and transportation costs. She works six days a week and depends on this job for her living. 

Florence joined MCDT because she wanted to boost her business by getting additional capital.  She resides in and owns a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her monthly expenses includes school fees, food, and paying utility bills.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Kweyamba Womens, Namawojjolo-Lugazi Group

texts.en:
37-year-old N. Zam is an optimist; she prefers looking on the positive side of things even when circumstances are not in her favor. She says this has saved her soft drink business from running into the many stonewall challenges that often strike at the root of small businesses like hers. Fifteen years is the time she has been in this business. Her longevity she says is all due to her zeal, involvement, hard work and determination. 

Zam began this business with savings from her farming business. She bought a refrigerator first. In a week, she makes profits that add up to 100,000 shillings. With these she has been able to cater well for her family's needs. With this loan, she wants to purchase more crates of soda and also buy another refrigerator.

loans.use: The purchase of more crates of soda and a refrigerator

loans.name: Justine

texts.en:
Justine is a single parent with five children; two of them are at school.  She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Kalerwe market selling second-hand clothes. Justine buys bales of second-hand clothes from Owino market and uses public transport to and from shopping. She wants to use this loan to buy more bales of second-hand clothes. She goes for shopping once a week.  She has been in this business for the last seven years.  

Besides this clothing business Justine also sells pancakes and cassava to earn additional income. Her customers are the people in the market. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for her living.  Her business challenges include defaulters and transportation. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting selling wholesale only.  Justine decided to work with MCDT in order to get additional capital. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house but the family has no access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bales of second-hand clothes

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida S. is from the village of Brgy. Nagcuartelan, Aritao, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Aida is married and has 4 adult children. To make a living, Aida owns & operates a business venture in the food sector. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fruit and vegetables in the local community. Aida has been engaged in her business for over 9 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Aida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aida has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sale. Aida is requesting a new loan of 23,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Aida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Mr. Nuon Touch Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of seventeen people who live in Sameakki village in Takeo province. Mr. Nuon T., who was born in 1949, is the village bank president.  He was selected for this role by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan for varied purposes. 

Mr. Nuon T. and his wife, Mrs. Tol Boeng, are farmers who own a two-hectare plot of land on which they cultivate rice to sell to support their family. They have three children, one of whom arranges funerals, while the others are studying in a local public school. Since his child’s funeral business is going well he wants to expand it. So to help his child reach this goal, Mr. Nuon T. is asking for a loan to buy funeral fireworks for resale.

loans.use: To buy fireworks for resale

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 50-year-old married woman and has one child. She has established a clothing and shoe store in her town since 2008. With her business she became able to earn income, pay for her child's education, and help her husband with the household expenses. She always tries to display a new collection to attract customers to her shop. She is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 to expand her inventory of new collections. She hopes that her diverse selection of clothes and shoes will continue to generate good profits and enable her to expand her business even further. She expects her productivity and income to increase in the coming year.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: expand her inventory of new collections

loans.name: Nizarina

texts.en:
Nizarina T. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 28 years old and single. She has one infant child.

To make a living, Nizarina runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food and daily use products in the local community. Nizarina has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month.

In 2010 Nizarina joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nizarina is requesting her first loan from HSPFI, for 5000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Federiko

texts.en:
Federiko, aged 30 years, is a married father of four children aged between 10 and 3 years. He lives in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He owns a bicycle spare parts business and started as a mechanic one year ego. He wants to include motorcycle spare parts in his business in the near future.

He wants a loan to buy bicycle spare parts for resale.

loans.use: Purchasing bicycle spare parts for resale

loans.name: Monika

texts.en: Monika K. is currently in the business of selling bags of charcoal at her home and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal to sell.  Monika is 47 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to be able to open up charcoal store at the market.

loans.use: Stock more bags of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Buraima's Group

texts.en:
Today women play a vital role in their communities, in improvement of living standards and overall economic growth. When a foreigner goes to any local market in Kyrgyzstan, he can see that the majority of shop assistants and sellers are women. This occurrence shows that old stereotypes about women as housewives have begun to disappear. 

Buraima M. is the leader of this group. She is sixty-four. Both she and her husband are retired. However, Buraima prefers to lead an independent life and therefore still makes her living by cattle breeding. Besides, she and her husband obtain a pension, which amounts to 4400 soms a month. She combines cattle breeding with farming as she also possesses a piece of land where she grows potatoes and cabbage. Another source of income comes from selling milk. 

Buraima’s two sons are engaged in construction and sometimes help their mother in her activities. Due to these joint businesses, Buraima has successfully married off her sons and increased the total population of her livestock. Now Buraima needs a loan. She hopes that with this loan she will be able to buy two sheep. 

Buraima’s partners:

Rukiahon B., 54, is a mother of four children. Two of her sons are working in Russia. To make a living, Rukiahon and her husband are engaged in farming. Her husband is an excavator driver. As for Rukiahon, she grows cotton on a piece of land. Rukiahon hopes to obtain this loan and purchase mineral fertilizers.

Zamira A., 51, has three children. Her husband works in Osh city. As for Zamira, she breeds cattle and does odd jobs. She manages to earn two – three dollars a day. Zamira has applied for this loan to make repairs on their house.

Suvsara M., 76, is a widow. She lives with her grandchild and his wife. In her old age Suvsara continues to work and contributes to her family’s income by raising livestock and growing cotton. She has two cows and obtains a pension. Suvsara needs this loan to purchase mineral fertilizers. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a single mother of four children, all of whom are at school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. 

She plans to use this loan to buy more bags of feed for her chickens. She has been in this business for the last three years and has no additional income. Her customers are the local people around the area. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. 

Her business challenges are seasonality and the ever increasing price of feeds. She joined MCDT because of the good services provided and the low interest charged.   

Josephine’s monthly expenses are food, medication and school fees. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bags of chicken feed

loans.name: Analiza

texts.en: Analiza F. is from the village of Gappal, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 37 years old. Analiza is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Analiza runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Analiza has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2009, Analiza joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Analiza is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. This will be the second loan taken out by Analiza from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and as working capital

loans.name: Mrs. Veth Torn Village Bank Group

texts.en:
This village bank loan consists of thirteen people who live I. Sameakki village I. Takeo province. Mrs. Veth T., 36, is the village bank president.  She was selected for this role by the other members, who will use their portions of the loan for varied purposes. 

Mrs. Veth T. is a mother of three children, two of whom are enrolled I. local public school, while the youngest is five years old.  She works at her home as a pig breeder while her husband, Mr. Sokly Loem, is a fisherman, and also owns a threshing machine. Since her pig-raising is going well she wants to expand her businees. So to reach this goal, Mrs.Veth T. is seeking a loan to buy more piglets for breeding.

loans.use: To buy more piglets for breeding

loans.name: Johnson

texts.en:
Johnson M. M. is 35 years old and married. He has three children between the ages of 3 months and 8 years whom he hopes to give a quality education to the university level. 

His business is located at Egoji house at the heart of the capital city of Kenya and is well known by the name Nutro General Merchants. He has been selling glass and glass accessories to customers within the city and others from far and wide. He has been doing this business for five years now and has one employee. 

He says that this business is profitable and the major challenge he has is giving excellent customer service. However, he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to buy two glass-drilling machines and one glass-cutting machine to be able to drill and cut glass for clients as per their requirements. 

He sees himself owning his own plot in the future. He also hopes to grow his business and add more items that his customers demand. He describes himself as hardworking, dedicated and courageous.

loans.use: Two glass-drilling machines and one glass-cutting machine

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan P., 37 years old, is from the village of Bonbon, Sagay, Camiguin Province. Susan is married and has three school-aged children.

To make a living Susan runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop where she sells food and daily use products in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 7500 PHP a month.

In 2010 Susan joined HSPFI to improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Susan is requesting her first loan from HSPFI, for 5000 PHP, which she will use to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the additional revenue to expand her business.

About HSPFI

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note

To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Shama Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Shama Parveen is a resident of Ismail Nagar, a small district that is located in the city of Lahore, Pakistan. She is a housewife who does her household work and also assists her husband with his dairy business. They have been involved in this business for the last seven years. Their business provides them with approximately 12,000 PKR on every month, which enables them to meet the financial expenses of their family.

Shama helps her husband milk their buffalo. Presently, they have one buffalo, which produces an insufficient amount of milk. Therefore, Shama has applied for a loan from Asasah. With the loan amount, her husband will buy another buffalo and enhance his dairy business. 

Shama is hopeful that with the help of an increased milk quantity, her husband will be able to sell more of it and make more money.

loans.use: To purchase another buffalo

loans.name: Roselyn

texts.en: Roselyn J. is from the village of Liong, Guinsiliban, Camiguin Province. She is 33 years old. Roselyn is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Roselyn sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Roselyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2010, Roselyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Roselyn is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Roselyn from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand it. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Nazia's Group

texts.en:
Nazia lives in Lahore, Pakistan, with her husband and children. A very talented lady, Nazia owns and operates a clothes selling business. She does this work to support her husband financially. He sells the clothes assortment to nearby areas. Once a month he travels to different cities, such as Faisalabad and Multan, which is famous for its textiles, to buy the assortment of cloth for her business.  

Her husband is an electrician by trade who operates a shop in the market where he repairs electric items and generates income for the family. Nazia and her husband both are very hardworking and manage their businesses effectively. Nazia has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy tools that will help him repair more electric items easily.
  
Nazia is very sure that this investment in her husband’s business will bring more profit for him and his standard of living will get better.

loans.use: To purchase tools to repair electric items

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is widowed with five children, and all of them go to school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a charcoal stall in her home and sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. She buys from her place of work, and so doesn’t incur any transport costs to and from shopping. She plans to use this loan of 500,000 UGX to buy more bags of charcoal. She has no additional income. She has been in this business for the last eight years and her customers are people around the area. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. Her business  challenges are rainy season and thieves. She is aspiring to see her business grow big and acquire enough profits to buy a plot of land. She joined MCDT because of the low interest rates charged. Joyce resides in and owns a two-room house, and the family has no access to electricity or piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Dilaram's Group

texts.en:
In order for a person to lead his or her life in dignity and convenience, there have to be some proper conditions. Those conditions can be summarized as availability of water pipes, roads and electricity. If there are not such facilities, people are faced with the everyday hard work of bringing water in carts and building all water providing systems themselves. The heroes of our story are people who overcome these difficulties everyday, and continue to work hard in order to earn their daily bread. 

Dilaram K. is 49. She has raised six daughters. Her husband works in the Water Supply Department and obtains a monthly salary of 3,000 soms. Dilaram grows cotton and sells it in market. Two of her daughters are married and live with their families. The rest of her daughters help Dilaram at the cotton plantation. Dilaram’s monthly income constitutes around 7,000 soms. This business has allowed Dilaram to marry her daughters. Now, Dilaram needs a loan. She needs to buy mineral fertilizers and therefore hopes to obtain this loan. In the near future, she plans to purchase cattle for breeding. 

Dilaram’s partners:

Mamurahan M., 41, is a mother of three children. She is engaged in cattle breeding and selling milk. Her son helps her to look after the cattle. Her husband is also engaged in some business and manages to earn 4,800 soms. Mamurahan would like to increase the total population of livestock. She needs a loan to purchase sheep for feeding.
 
Abdimutalib A., 48, is a father of two children. His eldest son is 17 and his little son is five. To provide for the family, Abdimutalib is engaged in growing cotton and corn. His monthly income is 2,100 soms. Abdimutalib has applied for this loan to purchase mineral fertilizers and use the rest of the funds to complete the construction of the house.

Dildora T., 20, is single. She is preparing for marriage. Dildora is going to work after the wedding. She hopes to obtain this loan and use the funds to prepare her dowry.
 
--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance, a young and ambitious socially-focused MFI in Kyrgyzstan.

Mol Bulak Finance is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development on the basis of the 3-Ps concept - People (building human capital and taking care of its customers and the society as well), Profit (to be profitable to grow further) and the Planet (taking care of the environment). It is also the only MFI in Kyrgyzstan who delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about Mol Bulak and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and micro-finance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan - at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from the Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and Mol Bulak staff.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester E. is from the village of Bonbon, Sagay, Camiguin Province. She is 27 years old. Ester is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Ester owns and operates a specialized retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Ester has been engaged in her business for more than three years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ester joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali is a 39-year-old married man from Lebanon. Ali is the owner of a shoe store since 2008, with 7 years of experience as an employee in the same field, formerly with his brothers. Ali requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to buy new collections, especially before the coming holiday occasion, Ramadan. Ali believes that to stay in the market you have to keep in your store a wide variety of shoes so that clients won’t leave your store buying nothing, and you have to fulfill all tastes. This is Ali’s third time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, where every time he uses itfor the same goal, and he gets the requested result. Ali is proud of what he achieved since he stopped working with his brothers and hopes to expand his business to  wholesale in the future.

loans.name: Inmar

texts.en: Inmar is a 31-year-old man from Lebanon. He has been the owner of an amusement center since 2008, with 8 years of experience in this field of work. This is Inmar’s fourth time to request a loan from Al Majmoua, and he has a perfect loan repayment schedule. This time Inmar is requesting a loan in order to add new equipment to his business and do the necessary maintenance to the other machines. His clients are his neighbors, teenagers and foreigners. He started his business with the money he borrowed from a friend, and from his work he was capable of paying back the money to his friend and add extra equipment to his business.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John M. W. is twenty-six years old. He is married but does not have any children yet. His business is located at Kimbo, along a road in Thika town. Thika is the region in Kenya known for production of pineapples. 

John provides transport to the local people. He has been in this business for the last year. He says that this business is profitable, but the major challenge is the high cost of maintenancee of the motorcycle, e.g., fuel and spare parts. However he works very hard to keep his business doing well. 

He is using his loan of Kes 30,000 to buy a new engine and headstart gears for his motorcycle. In the future, he sees himself owning a fleet of motorcycles and leading in this business. He also dreams of having a vehicle for a taxi business. He describes himself as hard-working and innovative.

loans.use: New engine and headstart gears for his motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 57-year-old married woman with 2 children. One is still attending school. She has been working as a baker for over 10 years. Her freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of her village and neighboring towns. Her bakery is an important source of income for her family. She is requesting to borrow $1200 to renovate her bakery and add new decor because she is planning to expand her business and make more space to receive more clients. She is planning to continue expansion of her business and she is positive about the coming year.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: renovate her bakery and add new decor

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

loans.use: Purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy G. N. is forty years old, married and has three children aged between the ages of nineteen years old and fifteen years old. Her business is located at Murera Juja a very busy market at Thika. She operates a hardware store in which she has been selling pipes, bicycle spare parts and other items. She has been selling to the local people for the last five years.

She has provided employment to one person. She says that this business is profitable, and the major challenge she has is insecurity in the area. However, she works very hard to keep her business doing well. She is using her loan of Kes 70,000 to buy more pipes and bicycle spare parts to meet the demand of her customers. She sees herself having many hardware items to sell in the future. She wants to be a market leader in this kind of business. She describes herself as very hard-working.

loans.use: Pipes, bicycle spare parts.

loans.name: Zaituni

texts.en:
Zaituni is divorced with three children, and all of them are at school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She owns a retail shop in Naguru selling all types of merchandise like sugar, salt, soap and cooking oil. She wants to use this loan to buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and a jerycan of cooking oil. 

Besides this retail shop she also owns a pay phone as an additional income. She has been in this business for the many years. She sells her products from the shop, and her customers are local people around the area. She works seven days a week. She depends on this job for a living. She is aspiring to buying herself a plot of land. 

She joined MCDT because of they were giving out timely loans. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house, and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sugar, cartons of salt, boxes of soap and jerycans of cooking oil

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

To make a living, Cresbee owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop.  Cresbee has been in business for over one year and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Cresbee joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.

loans.name: Marie Egidia

texts.en:
Egidia was born in 1969 and is married with six children aged between 18 and 5 years old. Egidia has been in the restaurant business for eight years and she employs six people as helpers so that her business runs well. The hours of her restaurant are from 7 in the morning to 9 in the evening every day. 

After realizing that her investment is too low to increase her profit, Egidia is now requesting her second loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company in order to expand her restaurant qualitatively and quantitatively. With this loan, Egidia and her husband will be able to earn more profits, which will allow them to save money for the future and pay school fees for their children.

loans.use: To expand her restaurant business

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz lives in a historic city called Lahore in Pakistan. A very talented lady, Shahnaz makes and sells artificial flowers to financially assist her husband. She is good in her art and gets good number of orders every month. She receives orders particularly from gift shops because they sell them with flower vases.  

Her husband's name is S., who runs a spare parts shop in the main market. He specifically sells motorbike spare parts in his shop, which he buys from “Bilal ganj,” a famous area for dealing in spare parts in Lahore.

Shahnaz has applied for a loan from Asasah to help her husband in his business. With the loan amount he will buy spare parts for his shop. 
She hopes that this investment will help her husband to earn more money than before. He will be able to provide better to his family as well.

loans.use: Purchase spare parts for selling

He primarily sells rice. He has vast experience in this. He is taking out a loan to increase his sales.

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en:
Sabah is the mother of one son and three daughters. Two of her daughters are married. The third daughter and her son are 14 and 16-year-old students, respectively. Sabah's husband, Khalil, sells vegetables and fruit from his booth in the vegetable market.

Sabah works in tailoring. She uses her income to pay for her son's and daughter's education expenses, while her husband's income pays for their household expenses. 

Khalil saved money to buy a shop to replace his vegetable booth. He considered borrowing money from his friends to complete the transaction, but Sabah decided to come to FATEN instead and take a loan for this purpose.

Khalil appears in the picture because Sabah is a conservative woman.

loans.use: Purchase a vegetable shop

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria M. is from the village of Sipaloc, Sibutad. She is 38 years old, married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Maria raises and sells piglets in the local community.  She has been in business for over 13 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Maria joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Maria has successfully repaid a previous loan of 2,000 PHP from PMPC, used for personal purposes.  Maria is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP for additional working capital. This loan will be her 4th from PMPC. 

------------------------------------------

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

texts.en: Florence is married with eight children and all of them are in school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members.  She owns a charcoal store in Kyebando Nsooba market. She works six days a week. Her business challenge is seasonality. She resides in and rents a two-room house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.  Florence’s monthly expenses include school fees, food and rent.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 31-year-old married man who has one young child. In 2007, he started his own business as a farmer with eight years of previous experience. He learned this occupation from his father who also works as a farmer. He owns a large piece of land where he cultivates multiple types of fruits and vegetables according to the season. He delivers the harvest to a big vegetable market in his town and to some small markets. He is thankful for his business income and he plans to make more profit by adding more cultivation. He is requesting $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a farming machine to renovate his soil and add more seeds to expand his production.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase farm machinery

loans.name: Khairan's Group

texts.en:
Khairan lives with her family in a city called Lahore, which is also known as “the heart of Pakistan”. She is a working lady. She sells bangles and ready-made clothes to share the financial burden with her husband. Her husband is a fruit vendor. He sells fruit by going to different areas of the community on his bicycle. He visits different places in the city to sell his fruit. He earns approximately 12-15 thousand PKRs every month, which has become insufficient to meet the financial expenses of his family. Because he used to buy fruit on a daily basis, he has to pay first. Now he has decided to start supplying the fruit to different fruit shops so he gets the required income with profit on the same day. 

Therefore, Khairan has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan, he will be able to buy seasonal fruit in bulk and sell it to more fruit shops. She is hopeful that, in this way, her husband can increase his income sufficiently.

loans.use: To purchase fruit for fruit selling business

loans.name: Sella Atieno

texts.en: Sella Atieno A. started her tailoring business in 2005 immediately after finishing her training.  Since then she has been playing a big role in their family upkeep. She is 46 years old, married and has four (4) children. She lives in Nyamasaria. Her business has started experiencing an influx of customers making more demands than she can supply. It is for this reason that she has requested for a loan of Ksh. 20,000 to enable her increase her stock to meet the demand. She buys her stock in Kisumu on a weekly basis.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 40 years old and married with three children.  Christine is a self-employed businesswoman known for selling a variety of goods in her small shop.  Christine opens her shop from 6 am until late in the evening hours.  

After four years in this business, her capital is still too low to earn more profit.  To end this, she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With the use of this loan, Christine will invest in foodstuffs such as rice, beans, peas, wheat etc.  As these foodstuffs are highly demanded, Christine hopes that she will attract more customers and, in addition, she will earn more profits.  With these earned profits, she will do her best to have better financial stability.

loans.use: To purchase a variety of foodstuffs

loans.name: Everlyne

texts.en:
Everlyne A. O. is twenty one years old. She is married with three children, aged between one and five years. Her husband is a casual laborer.

Everlyne's business is located at Nyamasaria in Kisumu. She also sells her items door to door in the Nyamasaria area. She sells plastic items like basins, mugs, plates, buckets, water tanks and other items. She has been engaged in this business for ten years. She says that this business is profitable. Her major challenge is that other people in the area offer the same products as hers; competition is very high. However, Everlyne works very hard to keep her business doing well.

She is using her loan of Kes 20,000 to buy plastic basins and plastic water tanks to meet her customers' demands. She hopes to diversify in business by beginning a fish processing business.

She hopes to improve the living standards of her family as well. She describes herself as a caring and loving mother.

loans.use: To purchase plastic basins and plastic water tanks

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 59 years old. He is married and has been blessed with six children aged between 10 and 18 years old. Four of the children attend school.

James has been operating his mixed farm in Kisii town, Western Kenya for over 20 years. He has employed two people from his community. His farm produces beans, millet, vegetables, maize and milk, which he sells to the local market. He solely depends on the income from farming to fulfill the needs of his family. His primary challenge has been debtors who don't pay their debts.

James has requested this loan from Juhudi Kilimo of 70,000 KES to purchase a dairy cow. He says that the proceeds from the sale of milk will enable him educate his children and finish building his house. In the future, he plans to expand his vegetable business by growing more vegetables and exploring more markets.

He is grateful to Juhudi for being there to support them.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard has been operating his mixed farm in Kisii town, western Kenya, for the last fifteen years. His farm produces maize, milk, beans, vegetables and eggs, which he sells to the local retail market. He employs one farm-hand. He also operates a retail shop where he sells new clothes.

Richard recently completed his previous loan of 45,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo and has requested this loan of 70,000 KES to expand his cereal business. He says that the profits from this loan will enable him to pay school fees for his children and build a house for his family.

Richard’s primary challenges have been the high cost of transportation, poor prices for his cereals and poor weather patterns that affects his production. He is grateful to Juhudi for helping to eradicate poverty.

loans.name: Josiah

texts.en:
Josiah has been operating his mixed farm in Kisii town, western Kenya, for the last ten years, selling his products to the local market. He also owns and operates a motorbike in the same area.

Josiah is 38 years old and is married with eight children between the ages of 4 months and 14 years. Six of the children are currently attending school.

Josiah has requested this loan of 85,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a dairy cow. He says that with the income from the sale of milk he will be able to provide for the needs of his family. His biggest challenges have been the high competition in the market, a lack of skills in animal husbandry, diseases, and lack of farm inputs.

In future, Josiah would like to have at least five quality cows that daily produce ten liters of milk each. He says that Juhudi is a good company that has changed people's lives a great deal and he has a strong hope for further progress with Juhudi.

loans.use: To purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia F. is from the town of Baclayon. She is 41 years old and is married with four school-aged children.

Lucia's main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motorcycle transport services or habal-habal (a motorcycle with an extended seat that carries 2-6 passengers). Lucia has been engaged in her business for over seven years.

Lucia joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to repair her existing vehicle to provide better service. This loan will be her first from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save for an additional motorcycle.


About CEVI: 
Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.

CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

loans.name: Seleman

texts.en:
Seleman was born in 1977 and he is married. He owns a business selling various products such as looking glasses and watches. Seleman's wife is a businesswoman. They both work hard for the benefit of their family. Seleman's business is profitable and well organized. He employs one person as a helper so that his business runs well. Seleman has one year and half years of experience in his business. The hours of his shop are from 8 in the morning to 7 in the evening, every day except on Saturday.

Seleman is requesting his first loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company to expand his business by purchasing more products for selling.
