Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase children's clothing for resale

loans.name: Maha

texts.en:
Maha Dawaseh is a 26-year-old mother of three daughters and two sons. Her husband, Jamal, owns an electronics store where he sells new and used appliances, such as refrigerators, recorders, and microwaves. Maha's husband started the business four years ago with very little capital. The business is prospering, so Maha and her husband decided to improve the store and make a few changes.

Maha took a $1,500 loan so her husband could use it to change a few things in the store, like display equipment, wall painting, etc. 

In the photograph, Jamal stands in front of the electronics that he sells, because Maha comes from a conservative background.

loans.use: Improve her husband's electronics store

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en:
Nodira, a sharp, energetic entrepreneur from Dushanbe, Tajikistan, started her own clothing business 16 years ago and has built a successful enterprise. She has a good location in the market for her sales, along with an attractive display of clothing for passing customers. Nodira is a married woman with three children, and her income helps her to support her children's pursuit of a good education. Nodira has requested a loan of 7500 Somoni so that she can purchase new clothing inventory. This loan will allow her to increase her income by having the right clothing available to meet seasonal demand. Over the last three years, Nodira has proven to be a great loan client with IMON International, and we are glad to have this new opportunity to continue assisting her with her business.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase clothing to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Ayten

texts.ru:
Ayten Xamedovoy 32 qoda . Ona zamujem. Ona jivet v regione Absheron. Eta molodaya devushka uchilas v universitete bataniki i posle okonchaniya  universiteta ona reshila rabotat s rasteniyami uxajivat zanimi izuchat ix a tak je i potom prodovat interesniye rasteniya.

Ayten nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit otrostki rasteniy dlya toqo chto bi virastit ix i potom prodast.V budushem ona xotela bi imet pobolshe mesta dlya virashivaniya rasteniy tak je imet ochen redkiye rasteniya v svoyom maqazine dlya prodaji.
texts.en:
Ayten X. is 32 years old. She is married. She lives in the Absheron region. This young woman studied botany at the university. After graduation, she decided to work with plants, caring for them, studying them, and selling interesting plants. Ayten needs 2000 AZN to buy plant clippings in order to grow and later sell the resulting plants. In the future, she would like to have a larger space for growing her plants, rare plants, and her own store.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying plants

loans.name: Faizali

texts.en:
B. Faizali is 49 years old. He is married with three children. After getting married, he arduously dedicated himself to the livestock business. When he recognized the need to invest in his work, Faizali decided to construct a place to keep his animals and for this he requires certain construction materials to accomplish the task at hand. Trustingly, he has sought IMON believing that his loan request will be granted and with this he will be able to move forward in his work. With the loan, Faizali will purchase young cattle and construction materials for improving his cattle-shed.     

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing of young cattle and construction materials for improving his cattle-shed

loans.name: Perveen's Group

texts.en:
Perveen is married to M.; they both live in a city called Borewala in Pakistan. Borewala city is famous for its shrines. She is a housewife who stays at home and takes care of her family. 

Her husband is involved in a timber-selling business. He sells timber at his shop. He has six years of experience in this business. His shop is located in the main market of Borewala. This place is always busy with people. All the necessary things can be found easily there. 

Parveen has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband. With the loan amount, he will buy timber in bulk and expand his business. 

Parveen is hopeful that this investment will be helpful for her husband’s business, and he will increase his profits and his family will be able to have a better standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase timbers for timber selling business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The Kiva borrower is a 33-year-old single woman living with her parents. She is a beautician who has developed her business in her home where she receives clients. She has more than 10 years of experience in this business. She also works as a traveling beautician offering her beauty services in clients’ houses. This is her second loan; she has been a reliable borrower with on-time repayments throughout her loan cycle. She has also decided to repay her full loan amount several months early. She is requesting $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase beauty products and supplies needed to increase her business productivity. In the future, she hopes to open a small beauty shop where she can continue her work full-time.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: purchase beauty products and supplies

loans.name: Momoh

texts.en:
Momoh G. is a 52-year-old businessman. He is hardworking and very determined.  Mr. G. was a tailor; he was able to access Le 400,000 from his tailoring activity and began a food items trade. Now he trades in electrical appliances, which he has done for three years.  

He is married to businesswoman. Mr. G. and his wife have five children. 

Mr. G. has a very good credit rating and needs a loan of Le 4,000,000 to buy more electrical materials. He intends to use the proceeds from his loan to educate his children to the university level and construct a dwelling house for his family.

loans.use: To buy more electrical materials

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia lives in a city called Borewala, which is a part of Punjab, Pakistan. 

She is a housewife who stays at home, manages the household chores and takes care of her family. 

Her husband's name is I. M.. He works as a driver. He drives a rickshaw that he renst. Working on a rented rickshaw is never satisfying, even after working very hard. 

Razia wants to help her husband buy his own new auto rickshaw, which will not only avoid the cost of rent, but he will also be able to work for longer hours, which will earn him more money. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for this purpose. 

Razia is not satisfied with her current financial situation, but she is sure that with the loan her husband will lead his family towards a better standard of living.

loans.use: Purchase a new rickshaw

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is a 24-year-old man from Tulkarem. He is a Palestinian National Authority employee with a $290 salary. Muhammad also works in a plant nursery. 

Muhammad has a degree in nursing, but because he couldn't find a job in a hospital or medical center, he works for the Palestinian National Authority.

Muhammad is engaged and planning to get married this summer. Because his sources of income are limited, he took a $3,000 loan from FATEN to pay for his wedding expenses.

loans.use: Pay for his wedding expenses

loans.name: Elizabeth Kasaya

texts.en:
Elizabeth Kasaya O. is 28 years old. She is married and is the happy mother of four children. Ever since she got married, Elizabeth has always been in business as she aspires to be an independent woman though married.

Elizabeth started with charcoal selling, but with things not going the way she planned, she decided to quit and started farming in 2007. Since then, she has excelled with all her produce getting buyers who come for them at her farm in Nyamasaria.

Elizabeth would like to expand her business in order to meet the rising demand and improve her living standard. She wishes to obtain a Ksh 30,000 loan to boost her business.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mohamed Alie

texts.en:
Mohamed sells electronic appliances in the city center of Makeni. He is a cool and courageous businessman. He initially accessed funds from his elder brother and started selling cassette tapes ten years ago.

Mohamed is married to a trader and has one child and two dependents.

Mohamed has a good loan repayment history. He needs this loan to buy more electronic appliances. He hopes to use the proceeds of the loan to educate his children to university level and to construct a house.

loans.use: To buy additional electronic appliances

loans.name: Jacinta Atieno

texts.en:
Jacinta Atieno A. does farming as a business in Nyamasaria, Kisumu. She started this business in 2007 after quitting vegetable selling which was not earning her sufficient income. She purchases her stock monthly.

With a family of five children, Jacinta wants to expand her business to generate more income so as to be able to effectively support her husband in taking care of the family’s needs. She would like, therefore, to obtain a Ksh 30,000 loan to give her business a boost.

Jacinta is 30 years old and is married. She has a dream of being independent.

loans.use: To invest in expanding her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Aliaskar

texts.ru:
Aliaskar A. i eqo semya jivut v regione Absheron. Emu 54 qoda. On jenat i imeyet 3 detey kotoriye uchatsya v shkole i zanimayustay tancami, sportom i muzikoy.

Aliaskar zanimayetsya perenosom pasajirov v razniye regioni uje 10 let. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit zapchasti dlya mashini chtobi otremontirovat i sdelat mashinu udobnim dlya passajirov.
texts.en:
Aliaskar A. and his family live in the Absheron region. He is 54 years old, and married. He has three children who go to school and study dance, sports, and music. Aliaskar has been working in different regions transporting passengers for ten years. Now, he needs 2000 AZN to buy parts for his car in order to repair it and make is comfortable for passengers.

Translated from Russian by Melissa Kniazeva, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying car parts

loans.name: Ala

texts.en:
Ala is a 28-year-old man from Gaza City in the Gaza Strip. Ala is a hard-working single man who takes care of his elderly parents and looks after his younger brother. 

Ala started working as a barber eight years ago when he found a well-located shop and took a training class.

Ala decided to replace his old barbering tools with new ones. He also wants to buy supplies for his job, such as creams. Ala came to FATEN and took a $1,000 dollar loan for this purpose.

In the photograph, Ala appears in his shop.

loans.use: Purchase tools and supplies for his barber shop

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan J. B. is a thirty-eight-year-old lady who is married to Joseph Kosgei. They are blessed with four beautiful children and live in Mafuta in the outskirts of Eldoret Town. Joseph, like Susan, is a farmer and together they plant maize and wheat to sell after harvest.

Susan has been a farmer for eight years now, earning a monthly income of 12,500 shillings. This will be her third loan from KADET and she plans to use it to buy fertilizer for her farm. She anticipates earning a profit which she will use to expand her farming business and even hire more land for planting maize and wheat.

In the future, Susan hopes to expand her farming, become a better farmer, and also support her family by providing their basic needs.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for her farm

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is separated and has four children. He is a hardworking and dedicated trader in cassettes (video and tape) and electronic appliances. His shop is located along Rogbaneh Road in Makeni.
Abass has sixteen years' experience in business. He is requesting a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to buy more electronic appliances and cassettes. He wants to buy more modern videos and televisions to meet the tastes of his customers. This is his second successive loan, and for the past year he has made all his loan repayments on time. He hopes to use the proceeds of his loan to educate his children to university level and buy some land, which will be

loans.use: To buy more electrical appliances and cassettes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more food items for his stall

loans.name: Jerusalem Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité JÉRUSALEM est créé depuis trois ans. Il est composé de 12 femmes  toutes militantes de l'Association des femmes Catholiques de la Paroisse de Louga. Elles sont de la même communauté ecclésiale de Base et sont très engagées dans les activités de la Paroisse.

Madame Eliane N., debout à gauche de la photo est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 51ans. Elle est veuve et mère de 03 enfants. Elle est tutrice de 8 enfants confiés par des proches. 

Elle fait un petit commerce de produits halieutiques. Comme activité secondaire elle pratique la vente de citron et d'huile de palme. 

Son prêt lui permettra d'acheter plus de marchandises et faire ainsi l'extension de son petit commerce.

Avec Ses bénéfices elle assure en plénitude la prise en charge, la nourriture et la santé de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The Jerusalem solidarity group was formed three years ago. It is made up of 12 women, all active in the Association of Catholic Woman of Louga parish. They all belong to the same church community and are actively engaged in parish affairs. Mme Eliane N., standing at the right of the photo, is the group's leader. She is 51, a widow with three children, and cares for eight neighbor children. She has a small business selling fish, citrus, and palm oil. Her loan will allow her to buy more stock and to grow her business. Her profit will enable her to pay for her children's nutritional and health needs.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fish products

loans.name: Mariatu

texts.en:
Mariatu is 30 years old. Her business is located along the main Market Road in Makeni. She has been selling gara (locally dyed) clothes for the past four years. Mariatu is a dedicated and very determined businesswoman. She starts work at 7.00am and returns home at 6.30pm. She was able to access funds from her relatives to begin her trade in gara clothes.
Mariatu has a very good loan repayment history. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help her buy more gara materials for resale. In this way, she will make more profit. She intends to use the proceeds of this loan to pay college fees.

loans.use: To buy gara (locally dyed) clothes for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase tools

loans.name: Ya Alimamy

texts.en:
Ya Alimamy is a hardworking businesswoman who has been in business for the past 20 years. She runs a foodstuff and provisions shop in partnership with her husband. Her shop is located in the far west business district in Freetown city. Ya Alimamy and her husband are in their late fifties. They have five children; all of them are now independent.
Ya Alimamy has a very good loan repayment history with Kiva partner, Association for Rural Development. She needs a loan of 4,000,000 SLL to help her buy more stock for her shop for wholesale purposes. With the proceeds from this loan she wishes to help her grandchildren and their dependants in school.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for her shop

loans.name: Aliyev

texts.ru:
N. Aliyevu 47 let . On jenat i imeyet 3 detey. N. i eqo semya jivut v regione Absheron. Natiga detyam devochke 13 let, sinu 15 let i starshemu sinu 20 let. 

N. zanimayestay etim biznesem remonta mashin uje 7 let. Teper on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chto bi kupit zapchasti dlya remonta mashin. V budushem on xochet razvit svoy bizness i uvelichit pomesheniye qde on rabotayet chtobi tuda pomeshalis bolshe mashin.
texts.en:
N. Aliyev is 47 years old. He is married and has three children. N. lives with his family in the Absheron Region. His daughter is 13 years old, and the sons are 15 and 20 years old. He has been in the auto repair business for seven years already. At present he needs 2000 AZN to purchase spare parts. In the future he would like to develop his business further and expand his shop in order to be able to accommodate more cars.

Translated from Russian by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing spare parts

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline J. is 33 years old and a widow. She has two children, and they do not go to school. Jackline is currently in the business of selling ice cream, juice and bread at the market. She is requesting a loan to stock more sugar and fruits to make more juice to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to send her children to school.

loans.use: To stock more sugar and fruits to make more juice to sell

loans.name: Susan Akeyo

texts.en:
Susan Akeyo O. owns a grocery store where she sells fruit and vegetables in Nyamasaria Kisumu. She started this venture in 2007 after quitting cereal selling. She buys her stock three times a week from Sondu and Kibuye markets.

Susan wants to boost her business by increasing her stock and it is for this reason she has applied for a loan of Ksh 20,000.

Susan is 51 years old, is married, and is the mother of four children. She has a dream of expanding her business further.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Gakuweebwa Munno Developement Group, Mityana

texts.en:
40,000 shillings as weekly profits for a retail business operating in a far off distant metropolis like Mityana is not a bad bargain, given the lower operational costs one incurs in comparison to more expensive places like Kampala. The example of 34-year-old N. Joelia, who has for the last two years been operating her retail shop in Mityana town, is testament to that. The good rapport Joelia has struck with her existing and new customers has been her winning magic formula.

This married mother of four has come quite a long way in establishing a firm foothold in her business. She used profits from this business to improve her family’s welfare in a relatively short period of time. With this loan, she wants to buy more general merchandise for her enterprise. For the most part, she wants to buy bags of rice, plastics goods and edibles to sell.

loans.use: To purchase bags of rice, plastics goods and edibles to sell

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella Paoulina is currently in the business of selling hair-weaving materials at her salon and is requesting a loan to stock more hair-weaving materials to sell.

Estella is 39 years old and is married to a businessman. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to employ an expert to treat hair for the customers in her salon.

loans.use: To stock more hair-weaving materials to sell

loans.name: Beatrice Atieno

texts.en:
Beatrice Atieno O. is a fish vendor, a business she started in 2006. Before that, she used to operate a salon but, due to low income, she had to ditch it.

Beatrice buys her stock directly from the lake because the fish are cheap there. To improve her business, she has applied for a Ksh 10,000 loan.

Beatrice is 31 years old, is married, and is the mother of two children. Her dream is to be economically stable.

loans.use: To improve her business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Theodette

texts.en:
Theodette is 45 years old and is married with eight children who are between 8 and 23 years old.

Theodette is well-known in the business of selling different items, mainly building and electrical items. Her business hours are from early in the morning until late in the evening. She has been in this business for about two years.

Theodette needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a in order to expand her business. With this loan, she will hopefully increase the number of her customers as well as her profits. With these profits, she will keep reinvesting in her business for better financial stability. This, in turn, will allow her to continue taking care of her family and save for the future.

loans.use: To buy a variety of electrical and building items

loans.name: Lilian

texts.en: Lilian K. is currently in the business of selling charcoal out of her home  and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of charcoal  and some firewood to sell.  Lilian is 39 years old and is married to a husband who is a peasant. She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a real charcoal store.

loans.use: Store more bags of charcoal  and buy some firewood to sell

loans.name: Eunice Atieno

texts.en:
Eunice Atieno A. has been selling cereal since 2006, a business she started after quitting chips-selling which didn't have a good turnover. She buys her stock in Kibuye on a daily basis since the business is still small and she has no storage facility for bulk quantities. She plans to expand the venture and to do so, she has applied for a loan worth KSH.10,000 from KMET-KIVA micro-finance initiative. She is optimistic that this will enable her to achieve her dream of operating a wholesale business.

She is 29 years of age, married and a mother of three children.

loans.use: To increase her stock of cereals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 47-year-old married woman and mother of 3 school-aged children.  She is a relatively new business owner—she opened her own mini-market almost two years ago. She sells food products, cereals, detergents, bread, soft drinks, etc. Today, she is requesting to borrow US$ 1,000 to increase her store inventory in order to increase her sales and thus her income. Her business income is important to help support her husband and children.

It is very common in Lebanon to find small supermarkets  selling perishable and non-perishable goods. As members of the communities themselves, store owners have a deep understanding of local consumer needs and can offer products that meet local demand. The strong network of community relationships is an important component of life in Lebanon, especially in smaller towns and villages.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:
Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: increase her store inventory

loans.name: Kuteesa Womens Group-Lugazi

texts.en:
Most people in Uganda have done their utmost through the years to get a settled means of living through subsistence and commercial farming. With this genre of business, it has always been an assured flood tide of financial success whether in the short term or in the long term. Even in the event of drought or famine, many farmers have banked on their reserves to make ends meet. It is therefore surprising to see a person dispense with this kind of lucrative venture. 

45-year-old K. Efulansi decided to go against this grain and made her farming business a subsidiary business 30 years ago. Her deduction was that she would be able to make more profit selling charcoal. She however still maintained her farming business though it now played second fiddle to charcoal sales. With hard work and determination, this married mother of 4 school-going children has achieved her goal. 

In Luleeka, Lugazi where she operates, she has carved out a reliable niche for her business. This explains why her business is still going strong notwithstanding the competition she faces. In a month, she makes profits to the tune of 100,000 shillings. With this loan, she wants to buy more bags of charcoal for resale.

loans.use: purchase more bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Jackline Kemuma

texts.en:
Jackline Kemuma K. is 32 years old and a single mother of two children. After losing her job she started selling and supplying eggs in Kisumu, where she also stays, to support her family. She travels to Nairobi on a weekly basis to purchase her stock. 

Jackline wants to expand her business since it’s the family’s only source of income and to do this, she would like to get a loan worth Ksh.10,000 which will be used to increase her stock. Her dream is to expand her business and gain more income to help her educate her children.

loans.use: Expand business

loans.name: Unice

texts.en: Unice K. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes and green vegetables at the market and is requesting a loan to stock fish to sell.  Unice is 40 years old and is widowed.   She has four children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house, put it up for rent, and use the rental income to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock fish to sell

loans.name: Catherine Achieng

texts.en:
Catherine Achieng O. is a married woman and a mother of five children. Immediately after she dropped from school in 1985, she started a fish-vending business, something that has been able to generate her income to date. 

She decided to join KMET, where she was trained in business and financial management. With such skills, she believes that her business will diversify further. She would wish to get a loan worth 10,000 Kenyan shillings to help her expand her business to generate more income and support the family effectively.

loans.use: Expand business

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Morris

texts.en:
Morris is 60 years old, married and a father of five. He has only one child who is still in school. He sells second-hand clothes and household items such as seats, gas cookers and fridges. He has been engaged in this business for over 10 years and has two employees.  

He is a member of the Mwangaza group in Faulu Kenya whose members are responsible for any member who takes out a loan. So far, he has taken out one loan from Faulu Kenya, which he used to boost the business and successfully repaid.  

He has requested another loan of 40,000 Kenyan shillings to hire a business premise and to add stock of clothes.

loans.use: To hire a business premise and to add stock of clothes

loans.name: Kiden

texts.en:
Kiden J.  is currently in the business of selling dried fish and tomatoes at the market and is requesting a loan to stock bags of rice and beans to sell.  Kiden is 21 years old and single. She has no children yet.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a house for rent.

loans.use: Stock bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Roger

texts.en:
Roger was born in 1983 and is single. Roger owns a small business selling various products such as juice, water, sugar, salt, bananas, and so on. Roger has chosen to do this business because it is profitable. Roger is a relatively new entrepreneur in this business because he has an experience of one year. The hours of his daily activities are from 6 in the morning to 8 in the evening every day. Roger employs one person as a helper so that his business runs well.

Roger is now requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business through purchasing more products. With this loan Roger will be able to satisfy his customers, which will allow him to earn more profit.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty A. is currently in the business of selling foodstuffs at her restaurant and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of local Sudanese beans (ful) to cook and sell.  Betty is 30 years old and is married with a husband that is a police officer. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to extend the floor of her restaurant and purchase more tables and chairs for accommodation.

loans.use: Stock more bags of local Sudanese beans (ful) to cook and sell

loans.name: Pauline

texts.en: Pauline is 28 years old and a member of Mwangaza group in Faulu Kenya.  She joined the group as an entrepreneur who offers computer services such as computer training, internet services, and photocopy services.  Her business is only one year old and she hopes to own a computer college. She has requested for 40,000 KES to buy two more computers.

loans.use: To buy two computers

loans.name: Angelina Selina Adhiambo

texts.en:
Angeline Selina Adhiambo O. is 45 years old. She is married and has four children. She started a water vending business in 2007 to meet her daily needs and that of her entire family after she quit selling shoes due to low income. 

With only one supply outlet, Angelina wants to have more--especially in areas with no water outlets at all--something that will see her earn considerable income. She wishes to get a loan worth 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) to expand her network of outlets as she works towards socio-economic stability for herself and her family.

loans.use: Create more water distribution outlets

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Rwakashoma Tea Growers, Bushenyi Group

texts.en:
N. Juliet is the leader of her lending group in Bushenyi. She is 42 years old and married, with 9 children of whom 8 are still in school. Juliet has a business of selling bananas from her home area by the side of the road, and she is happy to say that she continually has customers. She is able to make 30,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX) as weekly profits in addition to the income received from her retail shop. 

She is also a farmer and has banana plantations. This is one reason she needs a loan: to be able to mulch her plantations for increased output. She also wants to buy more matooke (steamed green plantain) for resale since at the moment, she cannot get enough to sell to her customers. 

Juliet appears in a Red T-shirt in the group photo; she is a very hard-working and determined lady. She is happy that she has enough food for her family and she is seeing her children through school.

loans.use: Buying more matooke (steamed green plantain) for resale; mulching a banana plantation

loans.name: Jenipher Achieng

texts.en:
Jenipher Achieng O. stays in Manyatta, Kisumu. She started a charcoal selling business in 2006 to generate income to help her husband in supporting their four children.

She buys her stock daily in Kibuye market and, despite the income generated from her business, she wishes to expand it and buy livestock. Therefore she has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings (KES) from the KMET-Kiva micro finance initiative for that.

She is 38 years old and her dream is to buy a plot of land and build rental houses.

loans.use: Expand business with purchase of livestock

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is married to a businessman, but has no children. She has been operating her retail shop for the last two years, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She rents a house with electricity and piped water.

With the 15,000 Kenyan shilling (KES) loan she wants to purchase four bundles of maize flour, wheat flour, 50 kg of sugar, and 30 litres of cooking oil. Naomi faces the major challenge of high transport cost. She hopes to open a wholesale shop in the future. Her main aim of working with Yehu is to get financial assistance and improve her business. She cites food as her greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase maize and wheat flours, sugar, and cooking oil

loans.name: Catherine

texts.en:
Catherine W. is currently in the business of selling both dried and fresh fish at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more fish and tomatoes to sell.  

Catherine is 31 years old and married to a driver. She has three children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a restaurant.

loans.use: Stock more fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Jensa

texts.en:
Jensa W.  is currently in the business of selling beans, rice, maize flour and pulses (legumes) measured by the cup and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to sell.  

Jensa is 41 years old and married to a major in the army. She has four children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a hotel.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Hanady

texts.en:
Hanady M. is currently in the business of selling cassava tubers, sweet potatoes and carrots and is requesting a loan to stock fish and tomatoes to sell.  

Hanady is 51 years old and widowed. She has five children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: Stock fish and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: George

texts.en:
George is 26 years old and married. He has a 2-year old child. He has been selling bananas for eight years. He was previously employed and decided to do this business because his income was not enough to support the family.  

He has been an active member of Faulu Kenya. He has managed to service two loans from Faulu Kenya. Therefore, he has seen his business improve tremendously. He needs to buy more bananas for resale. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenyan shillings. He hopes to sell his bananas on a wholesale basis in the future. In five years, he wants to open other outlets.

loans.use: To add stock of bananas

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 25-year-old single man living with his mother and one brother in Lebanon. This young man decided in 2008 to start his own business by providing Internet connections to his town and its surroundings. He has been involved in this type of occupation for the past four years. Despite his young age, he is taking care of his family with his business income. His story illustrates the day-to-day challenges many people are facing in trying to take care of household expenses, sick and aging family members, and at the same time run a business. Today, he is requesting to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase an Internet network in order to expand his business. This type of business is very common in Lebanon. Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers. About Ameen: Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese microfinance sector since 1999. Originally a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specializing in Microfinance. At Ameen s.a.l., we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes. Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: Purchase an Internet network

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a single mother of four children. Only two of the children are schooling; the rest are working. She also takes care of additional family members (old parents).  

She owns a bar in Kawempe, selling all types of beer and soft drinks like soda and mineral water. She has been in this bar business for many years. Sarah wants to use this loan to buy more crates of beer and soda and boxes of mineral water. She sells both on a retail and wholesale basis and sells to all categories of people. Sarah works seven days a week. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.  

Her business challenges include defaulters and the rainy season, which hinders her customers reaching her. She aspires to see her business grow big, to start selling only on a wholesale basis and also to get enough profits to buy a plot of land.      

She decided to work with MCDT because of their good customer care and also because they give out timely loans. Sarah resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees, rent and food.

loans.use: To buy more crates of beer and soda  and boxes of mineral water

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is widowed and has five children who all go to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. Esther owns a store at her home in in Kawempe from which she sells charcoal. She buys bags of charcoal from delivery vans which transport the charcoal from Luwero. She would like to use this loan to buy more bags of charcoal. Esther doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work. She has been in this charcoal business for a long time. Besides this charcoal business she doesn’t have any other side income. She sells both on the retail and wholesale markets and works seven days a week. Esther's business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She aspires to increase the size of her business and start selling only on the wholesale market. Esther joined MCDT because they were giving out timely loans. She resides in and owns a four-room house and her family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses include school fees, food and medication.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcaol.

loans.name: Zambonini Group

texts.es:
En la Compañía Zambonini distante de la Oficina de Paraguarí, se reunieron unas mujeres con el objetivo de  aumentar sus ingresos   y superarse cada día más, con el dinero que recibieron se les esta brindando la oportunidad de que ellas mismas crezcan y se dan cuenta que ellas pueden superarse y de esta forma poseer su propio capital de trabajo  para emprender alguna actividad productiva, 
El comité lleva por nombre C.M.R de Zambonini una de las integrantes es la señora Gladys quien se dedica a la confección de ropas para damas y caballeros.
Sus trabajos son muy apreciados pos los clientes y el ella tiene trabajo constantemente ya que recibe muchos pedidos.
Actualmente se encuentra con muchos pedidos de ropas para invierno, y necesita comprar algunos materiales para le trabajo.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de tela, hilos, accesorios de botonería para confección de ropas.
texts.en:
In the Zambonini company, far from the Office of Paraguarí, some women met with the purpose of increasing thier income and getting ahead day to day. With the money they received they are being offered the opportunity to grow and they realize that they can get ahead and own their own working capital to start a productive activity. The committee is named C.M.R de Zambonini. One of the members is Gladys, who makes clothes for men and women. Her work is appreciated by the customers and she constantly has work since she receives a lot of orders. Presently she has a lot of orders for winter clothing and she needs some materials for the work. She is asking for the loan to buy fabric, thread, and button accessories to make clothing.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabric, thread, and button accessories to make clothing

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Georffery

texts.en: Georffery is 35 years old and married with three children, aged 12, 11 and 10 months. He operates a retail shop to earn a living. He has been in the business for four years, but was previously employed in a supermarket. He was able to save part of his salary and managed to open his retail shop.  Being a member of Faulu Kenya, he has been trained on business management skills and this has helped him improve his business. Georffery has requested a loan of 30,000 KES, which he will use to purchase stock, including sugar, maize flour and soap.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory.

loans.name: Sope Serigne Babacar Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de Solidarité SOPE SERIGNE BABACAR est créé depuis le 30 décembre 2009. Il est composé de 31 femmes. Elles sont du même villageois. Elles se sont constituées en groupe par voisinage et par affinité. Elles font partie d'un des groupes du banc Villageois de PALENE COKI.

Madame Astou D. est âgée de 29ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont 01 garçon. Elle fait un petit commerce de savon en poudre, d'encens, de parfums, de colliers en perles, de pagnes et de chaussures. 

Elle a une ancienneté de 06 mois dans le Banc Villageois et en est à son second prêt
 
Avec son nouveau prêt elle va renforcer sa marchandise en s'approvisionnant en quantité plus importante. 

Son objectif est de soutenir financièrement son mari dans la prise en charge de la famille par exemple la nourriture et la santé.
texts.en:
The Sope Serigne Babacar solidarity group formed on December 30, 2009. The group is made up of 31 women from the same village who came together through friends and neighbours. The group belongs to the Palene Coki village bank.
Mrs. Astou D. is 29 years old. She is married and has three children, one of whom is a boy. She sells powder soap, incense, perfume, pearl necklaces, cloth and shoes.
She has been a member of the village bank for six months and is on her second loan.With this new loan, she’ll expand her stock by stocking larger quantities.Her goal is to help her husband cover family expenses like food and healthcare.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy powder soap, incense, perfume, pearl necklaces, cloth and shoes

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
The kiva borrower is a 28-year-old married man living with his wife in Lebanon. He has been working as a teacher since 2005 in a private school in his town. In addition, he works as a private teacher where he receives students in his home where he has prepared a special room for this purpose. He cooperates with his wife to satisfy their needs and they are thankful for their business income. Since he is planning to further developing his home business he is requesting to borrow $600 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a computer in order to facilitate his teaching preparation and to conduct more research to help his students.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: To purchase a computer.

loans.name: Víctor

texts.es:
Victor tiene 51 años de edad, vive en casa propia con su esposa de 50 años, tienen tres hijos dos de los cuales trabaja con él en su fábrica de costuras.
Victor aprendió el oficio de su tío con quien trabajo desde muy joven, a los 20 años viajo al Brasil de donde trajo capital suficiente para comprar sus màquinas y asi tener su propia fábrica de costura.
Actualmente trabaja con él dos de sus hijos y cinco jovenes mas de su barrio a quienes les remunera por los servicios relizados y a la vez les enseña el oficio.
Necesita el  crèdito para la compra de una máquina recta para mejorar su trabajo.
texts.en:
Victor is 51 years old and lives in a home of his own, along with his 50 year old wife and three children, two of whom work with him in his tailor shop. Victor learned this skill from his uncle with whom he began working when he was very young. At age 20, he travelled to Brazil and brought back enough working capital to buy his sewing machines and start his own tailor shop. At the moment, two of his sons and five other young men from his neighborhood work with him. He pays them for their work and at the same time trains them in the business. He needs this loan in order to buy a sewing machine in order to improve his work.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Sewing machine

loans.name: Bakyara Tutungukye Group, Ibanda

texts.en:
K. Jesca is a married mother with 7 children and she also takes care of three dependents. She has a restaurant business in Rwomuhoro Trading Center where she is able to generate 150,000/- as monthly profits. She has had the restaurant for 15 years and her biggest challenge has been having few customers but because of her good customer relations, she has been able to win many over to her side amidst stiff competition. 

Jesca's dream is to have a better equipped restaurant and educate all her children. This loan is to help Jessica with paying rent as well as buying more hotel equipment.

loans.use: Paying rent and buying other hotel equipment like plates and forks

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is a married woman with one child who is in school.  She also takes care of additional family members.  She is a tailor in Katanga making all types of fashions and designs.  She owns a shop that she works out of and has been in this business for many years.   Her customers are nearby schools and individuals who want their clothes sewn.  

Evelyn wants to use this loan to buy more clothing materials and thread. She doesn’t have any other source of income. She makes clothing both wholesale and retail. She works six days a week and depends on this job for a living. She buys her clothing materials from Kiyembe in Kampala city and uses public transport to and from shopping. Her business challenges include the rainy season and transportation.    

Evelyn is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting employing three girls.  Evelyn decided to work with MCDT because it was giving out timely loans. She resides in and rents a house which has electricity but no piped water.  Her greatest monthly expenses include food and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more clothing materials and thread

loans.name: Valentín

texts.es:
El Sr. Valentin  tiene 65 años, está casado con Nimia Meza  de 63 años quien se dedica a la costura, ayudando económicamente para el sustento familiar.
Tienen 3 hijos, todos  mayores  de edad, dos de los cuales ya son profesionales y uno está en la facultad, viven en casa propia.
Valentin comenzó como ayudante de su padre de quien aprendió el oficio, desde muy joven trabaja por cuenta propia, actualmente está trabajando con él un sobrino a quien le remunera y a la vez le enseña el oficio.
Su gomería esta bien ubicado por lo que tiene muchos clientes.
Hoy día ha aumentado la cantidad de vehículos y motos en la zona que hace que tenga mucho trabajo, además es muy conocido por la calidad de sus servicios, motivo por el cual es muy concurrida su gomería.
Necesita el crédito para la compra de neumáticos.
texts.en:
Valentín is 65 years old. He is married to Nimia Meza, 63, who is a seamstress and helps support the family financially. They have three children, all adults. Two of the children are professionals, and one is at school. They live in their own house. Valentín began by helping his father, from whom he learned the job. For 40 years he has been working for himself. Currently, he is working with a nephew whom he pays while teaching him the job. His tire shop has a good location next to an international route and a service station. These days the number of vehicles and motorcycles in the area has increased, giving him a lot of work. He is also well-known for quality of service, and for this reason his tire shop is very busy. He needs the loan to buy tires.

Translated from Spanish by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of tires for retail sale

loans.name: Yudaya

texts.en:
Yudaya is widowed with six children and all her children go to school.  She also takes acre of additional family members (grand-children). She owns a stall in Bwaise market selling bananas.  She has been in this banana business for a very long time and buys bunches of bananas from delivery vans which get them from villages. She doesn’t incur any transport costs as she buys from her place of work.  

Yudaya wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  Her customers are the nearby community.  She works in a semi-urban area and works seven days a week.   Her business challenges include the rainy season and thieves. She is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting going directly to farmers. She decided to work with MCDT because of low interest charged.  She resides in and owns a house but the family has no access to electricity or piped water.  Her monthly expenses include food, school fees, and medication.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 22-year-old single man living with his family in Lebanon. In 2007 he opened a car spare parts shop as his own business. His father takes care of the family expenses but the borrower is trying to help him with his business income as the majority of Lebanese children do.  

Despite his young age, he was able during this short period in the field to build up a good business reputation and he is thankful for his decision. He is requesting to borrow US$ 1,200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy more spare parts and enlarge his shop to meet the requirements of his customers and make a good income for his family. He plans to open a bigger store to sell spare parts and  one day, he would like to  open a commercial center.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e., blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, not indicating his/her name and location, etc.) Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

About Ameen:

Ameen s.a.l. has been a major player in the Lebanese Microfinance sector since 1999. Originally, a micro-credit program created by CHF International, Ameen evolved to become Ameen s.a.l. in 2003, a Lebanese services company. In 2007, Ameen s.a.l. registered with the Central Bank of Lebanon to become the first Lebanese financial institution specialized in Microfinance.

At Ameen s.a.l. we pledge to provide financial services to the largest number of micro and small entrepreneurs and to the working poor, to help them develop their businesses and improve their incomes.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loans Kiva to offer lower-interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high-quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: buy more spare parts

loans.name: Kayanga Development, Ibanda Group

texts.en: K. Ednah is the leader of her lending group in Ibanda. She is 40 years old and married with 4 school-going children aged between 10 – 18. She is in the business of selling produce from Kayanga and some of the sorts of produce that she sells are millet, beans, and groundnuts. In addition Ednah has rentals from which she gets a monthly income. She needs a loan to be able to buy more beans, maize and millet for resale so that she can make more earnings.

loans.use: Buying more beans, maize and millet for resale

loans.name: Barthazar

texts.en:
Barthazar is 54 years old and he is married.  Barthazar is widely known in the business of selling a variety of items.  Barthazar has been in this business for about 5 years and the hours of his business are from 7 am to 8 pm every day.

Barthazar needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to expand his business.  With this loan, Barthazar will start adding to his business the sale of foodstuffs (rice, sugar, beans, wheat, cassava, etc).  With the sale of foodstuffs, Barthazar hopes that his customer base will expand and thus his profits will increase.  With these profits, he will gradually keep reinvesting for a better financial stability.

loans.use: A variety of goods mainly foodstuffs

loans.name: Aidah

texts.en:
Aidah is married with five children and all of them are at school. She also takes care of additional family members.  She owns a stall in Bwaise selling bananas. She has been in this banana business for over ten years.  She buys bunches of bananas at her place of work and so doesn’t pay transport costs.  She plans to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas.  Apart from this banana business she doesn’t have any other side business. 

Aidah sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale and receives an average of 25 customers a day. She works seven days a week and depends on this job for a living.  Her greatest business challenge is seasonality because she works in a muddy place and this hinders her customers to reach her.  

Aidah is aspiring of seeing her business grow big and starting going to farmers directly.  Aidah joined MCDT because of low interest charged.  She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity but no piped water. Her monthly expenses include school fees and rent.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas

loans.name: C2883 Tujyinama Group

texts.en:
Vestine was born in 1971 and is married with three children. Vestine owns a small business selling water, tea and milk. This business is profitable in her residence place. Her business is known and organized. Vestine is the group leader of the group called TUJYINAMA in the local language. There are four members with various businesses. 

At present, Vestine and her group are requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding their businesses. With this loan, all the members of this group hope to earn more profit through satisfying more customers.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is married to a taxi driver with whom she has three children and all of them are at school. She also takes care of additional family members. She owns a restaurant in Katanga in the Wandegeya Kampala central division and works in a semi-urban area, selling all types of traditional food and chips.  She wants to use this loan partly to buy more foodstuffs like bunches of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes, cassava, jerrycans of cooking oil, and a second-hand refrigerator.  

Lucy has been in this business for four years and works six days a week.  She uses public transport to and from buying foodstuffs from Kalerwe market and goes for shopping three times a week.  Her business challenges include transportation and the rainy season.    

Lucy sells to all categories of people both retail and wholesale. She decided to join MCDT because they charge low interest. She resides in and rents a two-roomed house and the family has access to electricity and piped water.  Her greatest monthly  expenses are school fees, rent, and food.

loans.use: to buy more foodstufffs like bananas, cooking oil, sweet and Irish potatoes, bananas and a second-hand refrigerator

loans.name: Julies Margot

texts.es:
Julies de 49 años, vive en el Guasmo de Guayaquil (zona urbana, la mayoría de habitantes son comerciales informales), ella confecciona ropa y reparte en algunos locales. 

Hace 10 años comenzó a trabajar cuando se divorcio de su esposo, comenzando con una maquina de coser vieja pudo tener suficientes clientes para solventar sus gastos. Trabaja todos los días en su casa confeccionando pantalones, vestidos, blusas a sus clientes y así tener ingresos suficientes para darles una mejor vida a su hijo de 17 años. 

Para continuar con su taller de confección de ropa ella quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa y maquina de coser, en el futuro quiere trabajar con empleados y terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
Julies, 49, lives in Guayaqui’s Guasmo area (an urban zone most of whose residents are informal merchants). She makes clothes that she distributes to several stores. She started working 10 years ago when she divorced her husband. She started with an old sewing machine and acquired enough customers to be able to meet her expenses. She works every day making pants, dresses and blouses for her customers in order to have enough income to provide a better life for her 17-year-old son. To continue with her clothing manufacturing shop she wants to use the loan to buy clothes and a sewing machine. In the future, she’d like to hire employees and finish building her house.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For clothes and a sewing machine.

loans.name: Porfiria

texts.es:
Porfiria tiene 40 años; vive en casa propia, es casada, vive con su esposo, de 45 años de edad es vendedor ambulante  quien le ayuda para el ingreso familiar.
Tienen un hijo, de 14 años quien es estudiante esta en el octavo grado en la escuela.
Porfiria emprendió su  actividad   por iniciativa propia, viendo la necesidad de los pobladores de su   barrio que   no tenían  una despensa de donde comprar los  productos  básicos  para  la canasta familiar.

Actualmente su despensa es una de las más surtidas y cuenta con muchos clientes, precisa del crédito para la compra de un congelador.
texts.en:
Porfiria, 40, is married and lives in her own home with her husband, 45, who is an itinerant merchant and helps her meet household expenses. They have a 14-year-old son who is in 8th grade. Porfiria started her business on her own initiative when she saw the need her neighbors had for a neighborhood grocery store. They did not have a store where they could get the basic things they needed for their families. Currently, her store is one of the better stocked ones and she has a lot of regular customers. She needs the loan to buy a freezer.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a freezer.

loans.name: Seraphine

texts.en:
Seraphine is 54 years old, married with 5 children, and she takes care of two dependents.  Seraphine struggles  to earn the daily food for her children by sewing.  She has been in this business for about 15 years and the hours of her business are from morning until late in the evening hours.

Seraphine needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Seraphine plans to expand her business through purchasing 2 additional sewing machines and shift her small business  to another location where she can get more customers.  If successful, Seraphine will keep reinvesting in her business and start saving for a better future.

loans.use: 2 additional sewing machines

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en:
Harriet is married with six children and all of them are at school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She owns a restaurant selling all types of food like traditional and western food.  

She wants to use this loan to buy more bunches of bananas, Irish potatoes, beef, sweet potatoes and cooking oil. She buys these foodstuffs from Ndeeba market and incurs some little transport costs to and from the market. Besides this food business, she also owns rental rooms, which gives her additional income. She has been in this business for the last five years. She sells to all categories of people, both on a retail and wholesale basis. She works six days a week. 

She depends on this job for a living. Her business challenges are defaulters and the rainy season. She resides in and owns a three-roomed house and the family has no access to electricity or piped water.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of bananas, sweet and Irish potatoes, beef and cooking oil

loans.name: Nimia

texts.es:
Nimia tiene 57 años de edad, quien posee una despensa y tambien  se dedica a la venta de comestible, posee un puesto fijo en la cuidad de Sapucai.
Empezó con el negocio hace 28 años, cuenta con clientela formada es una de las despensas mas surtidas de la zona, pues no se encuentra dentro del casco urbano el negocio esta ubicado a 8 km de la cuidad  de Sapucai. Además tiene ventas de comestible, por la construción de la ruta asfáltica que une las cuidades de Paraguarí con Villarrica tiene mayor demandas de sus productos.
Es una señora  muy sacrificada, pues su horario laboral empieza a muy temprana horas de la mañana con la ayuda de su hermana, siendo que ella no tiene hijos.
Necesita el crédito para la compra de mercaderias, articulos de limpieza, mercería, librería, enlatados, empaquetados, para venta minorista, pues tiene mucha demanda por lo mencionado mas arriba.
texts.en:
Nimia, 57, has a grocery store and also sells food; she has a fixed sales booth in the city of Sapucai. She started the business 28 years ago and has a regular customer base. Her store is one of the better stocked ones in the area because it’s not located within the city limits but rather is 8 kilometers from the city of Sapucai. In addition, she sells food. Because of paved road construction work between Paraguari and Villarrica, she has increased demand for her products. She is a very devoted person because her work schedule starts very early in the morning. Her sister helps her because she doesn’t have any children. She needs funds to buy merchandise, cleaning supplies, miscellany, stationery items, canned goods, packaged goods to retail because she has a lot of demand due to what was mentioned above.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Kangulumira Aids Services Group

texts.en:
Most people supply the deficiencies in their salaries or low profits with odd jobs or they decide to concurrently run 2 or 3 businesses. From the point of view of a business, it is definitely an advantage when an individual bears a hand in many undertakings, the bottom-line being more profits.

S. John, 25 years old, makes 40,000 UGX per day from his business selling fruits and vegetables, primarily pineapples, jackfruits and passion fruits. For the past year, he has exhibited an enterprising and hardworking ethic that most young people of his age lack. He has won his laurels from his community of Kiwalasi-Kayunga, as the community leaders keep on saying that his example is one to be emulated by all young people. He is still a bachelor and has no children. With this in mind, he can look forward to a bright future. He is planning to purchase more fruits and vegetables in bulk with this loan.

loans.use: to purchase more fruits and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Darwin Alcivar

texts.es:
Darwin de 41 años, vive en las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas), el vende frutas y jugos naturales en el local que tiene en la parte delantera de su casa. 

Antes de tener su negocio el trabajaba vendiendo colchones pero como necesitaba mas tiempo para pasar con sus hijos puso un puesto de venta de frutas y batidos y para mas seguridad el tuvo que poner rejas en su negocio de frutas (como en la foto), trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 12h30 todos los días.  

Para poder tener mas variedad en su negocio el quiere implementar productos nuevos por eso con el préstamo quiere comprar un congelador, panes y lácteos. En el futuro quiere un local de desayunos y que sus hijo puedan termina con éxito sus estudios.
texts.en:
Darwin, 41, lives in Guayaquil’s Las Orquídeas area (an urban zone so-called because when it was discovered the area had many orchids). He is a fruit and natural juice vendor. He has a sales stand in the front part of his house. Prior to having his own business he was a mattress salesman but he wanted to spend more time with his children so he set up a fruit and fruit juice stand in his home. For increased security he had to install metal grilles in his business (as shown in the photo). He is open for business from 7am until 12:30 every day. In order to have more variety he’d like to add new products so he needs a loan to buy a freezer, baked goods and dairy products. In the future, he’d like to have a breakfast café and and he’d like his children to complete their schooling successfully.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For a freezer and dairy products.

loans.name: Clarisse

texts.en:
Clarisse is 34 years old, married with 5 children.  Clarisse makes a living by selling a variety of goods in her shop.  Clarisse has been in this business for about two years and the hours of her business are from 6 am to 7 pm every day.

After realizing that her capital is still too low to expand meaningfully, Clarisse decided she needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company s.a.  With this loan, Clarisse will start also selling foodstuffs and increase the sale of drinks in her existing business.  These additional businesses, as Clarisse realized, can bring in a lot of money.  She says that if this is successful, she will earn more money than previously and this amount will allow her to keep reinvesting in her business and start saving for the future.

loans.use: A variety of goods, mainly foodstuffs and drinks

loans.name: Clementine

texts.en:
Clementine was born in 1985 and is married without children. She owns a small business selling clothes in the city of Kigali. This business is profitable in the town and that's the reason why she chose it. Her business is well organized and known; Clementine has an experience of 10 years in this field. The hours of her daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 6 in the evening every day except on Saturday.

At present, Clementine is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding her business through purchasing more bales of clothes. This expansion will help her to satisfy her customers which will be one way of earning more profit.

loans.use: Expanding her business

loans.name: Tuliwalala  Womens Development Group-Jinja

texts.en:
N. Betty, 42 years old, is a stickler for hard work. If it was not for the extra hours and efforts she has been putting into her restaurant business, it could not have seen this longevity. Her strong resolve and determination carried her for 11 years down the tough stretch of running a cutthroat and competitive business. She cultivated these virtues whilst still running her farming business.

Each month, the restaurant generates 35,000 UGX and her optimism is high that her circumstances will improve once she accesses this loan. She is as happy-go-lucky and cheerful as they come, and her 6 children have taken after her. To supplement her restaurant business profits, she also operates a commercial motorcycle business and continues to run her farming business. With this loan, she wants to purchase a deep freezer for her restaurant, to cool her drinks.

loans.use: to purchase a deep freezer for her restaurant

loans.name: Socorro

texts.es:
Doña Socorro de 60 años de edad vive en la comarca Los Brasiles jurisdiccion de comalapa junto a su familia compuesta por su esposo el Sr. Carlos Davila y sus 2 hijos de 40 y 35 años de edad, los que le ayudan al cuido de la finca. Desde hace 40 años se dedica a la actividad productiva.   

Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de comprar terneros de desarrollo para engordarlos y posteriormente venderlos a un buen precio donde obtenga ganancias que le permitan  brindarle a su familia las condiciones necesarias del hogar.
texts.en:
Socorro, age 60, lives in the Los Brasiles region, which is in the Comalapa municipality. She lives with her family, which is comprised of her husband, Carlos Davila, and their two children. The children are 40 and 35 years old, and they help take care of the farm. She has been doing this work for 40 years. She is requesting her first loan to buy calves to fatten. Later, she will sell them for a good price. This will allow her to obtain the earnings that will provide her family with the necessary comforts at home.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy calves

loans.name: Maria Auxiliadora Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se encuentra trabajando actualmente con la Fundacion Paraguaya a travéz de la obtencion del crédito han podido algunos de los miembros emprender actividades que le puedan dan ganancias  como la venta de ropa usada,creación de almacén como asi tambien la ampliacion de la misma, han comprado chancho y pollitos. Para que las cuotas no les esfuerse tanto realizan  actividades comunitarias en donde venden comidas y solventan los gastos de pago mensuales.
La presidenta del comite es la señora Martina, quien se dedica a varias cosa en su  casa, ella tiene como actividades la compra y engorde de pollos para revender, tambien tiene cria de cerdos, y otras actividades agropecuarias, como en huerta y siembra de productos para el consumo de la familia.
Solicita el prestamo para la compra de pollitos, balanceados para el consumo de los cerdos y otros gastos que conlleva sus actividades.
texts.en:
This group is currently collaborating with Fundación Paraguaya. With help from the loan some of the members have been able to start activities that will produce profits for them. Some of these activities are: used clothes sales, set up and enlarging a grocery store, some have bought chicks and pigs. So that repayments won’t be too taxing on them they also engage in community activities where they sell food items in order to earn income to cover monthly expenses. The committee president is Martina who is involved in several activities in her home. She buys chicks to raise and then sell. She also raises pigs and is involved in other farming activities like growing vegetables for her family’s consumption. She is asking for funds to buy chicks, nutritionally balanced pig feed and for other expenses associated with her activities.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy chicks, pigs.

loans.name: Japhet

texts.en:
Japhet was born in 1971 and is married with two children; the first one is 6 and the younger is 2 years old. Only Japhet works in his family and that's the reason he has to work so hard to provide all the basic needs for his family. Japhet owns a small business selling phones in the city of Kigali; the hours of his daily activities are from 7 in the morning to 7 in the evening every day except on Saturday. Japhet has an experience of 9 years in his business.

Now, Japhet is requesting a loan from Kiva lenders via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of expanding his business so that he can satisfy his customers. When his customers are satisfied, hopefully Japhet will be able to earn more profit to reinvest in his business.

loans.use: Expanding his business

loans.name: Ramon Daniel

texts.es:
Don Ramon de 38 años de edad es casado, vive junto a su familia compuesta por su esposa y sus 4 hijos en la Comarca Piedra Pintada.  Desde hace 25 años se dedica a la explotacion ganadera y a la agricultura (siembra de trigo, frijol y maiz), ademas se dedica a la construccion y carpinteria dentro y fuera de la zona para asi obtener ingresos adicionales para el sustento familiar.   

Esta solicitando su 1er credito con el objetivo de comprar terneros de desarrollo y fortalecer su inventario ganadero.  

El mayor sueño de Ramon es poder consolidar su inventario para poder brindarle a su familia las condiciones necesarias del hogar.
texts.en:
Ramon is 38 years old and married. He lives with his family, who are his wife and 4 children, in the Piedra Pintada region. For 25 years, he has worked in livestock-breeding and agriculture (sowing wheat, beans and maize), and has also worked in construction and carpentry in the area and elsewhere. This allows him to earn extra income to support his family. He is requesting his first loan in order to buy young beef cows and strengthen his cattle inventory. Ramon's biggest dream is to make his inventory stronger to be able to offer his family the necessary household conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Kate Stansfield, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy young beef cows

loans.name: Anonymous
