loans.name: Ruqaiya's Group

texts.en:
Ruqaiya lives with her family and children in Mujahid colony, which is in the city of Borewala in Pakistan. A very talented lady, Ruqaiya runs a clothing business. She has been doing this work for over six years and has become experienced at it. She not only keeps herself aware of the new changes in fashion, but also manages her clientele base and takes care of their demands. Her customers feel good when they come to her to buy clothes, because she sells clothes at reasonable prices and also offers good clothing designs. She earns approximately 10,000 Pakistani rupees (PKR) from her business which is great support for her husband. He runs a carpet weaving business. He weaves carpets and earns good profit from it. He completes a carpet in three months and, in the meantime, Ruqaiya supports the family financially. 

Ruqaiya has applied for a loan from Asasah for her clothing business. With the loan, she will buy clothes in bulk and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for selling

loans.name: Welita

texts.en:
Welita M. is 32 years old, married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Welita engaged in hog raising and earns approximately 6000.00 a month out from selling of piglets in the local community. She has been operating her business for not less than a year.
  
In 2009, Welita joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC which was used to start a new business raising hogs. Welita is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase feed for her piggery. This will be her second loan from PMPC.

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Imelda G. is from the village of Mozzozzin Norte. She is 54 years old. Imelda is married and has 10 children. To make a living, Imelda runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Imelda has been engaged in her business for over 11 years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2009, Imelda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Imelda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell.

Imelda is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the third loan taken out by Imelda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Emalyn Sinay's Group

texts.en:
Emalyn S. is from the village of Sinuza, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is 31 years old. Emalyn is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Emalyn S. Group.

Emalyn is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Emalyn owns & operates a business planting & harvesting corn for sale. Emalyn has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3,800 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2006, Emalyn joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Emalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Emalyn is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the fifth loan taken out by Emalyn from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace J. K. is a woman of 48 years. She is married to David K. and together they are blessed with eight children. They live in the Mafuta area in the outskirts of Eldoret. She plants maize and wheat for resale after harvesting and has been in this business for 10 years now, getting a yearly income of 200,000 Kenyan shillings.

This will be Grace's second loan with KADET and she plans to buy fertilizer for her farm so that she can have a better harvest. With the income she is going to get from the sale of maize and wheat, she plans to expand her farming business and also use some money to feed the family.

In the future, Grace plans to buy a tractor to help her with digging her farm and also to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer for the maize and wheat
